item.title: ‘He’s clearly very clever’: Queen praises pooches trained to detect cancer at a dog charity event with Camilla – and tells one owner ‘I’m sure you can’t imagine life without him’
item.description: The Queen attended an event to mark the 10th birthday of the Medical Detection Dogs charity at the Royal Mews in London. She described the charity's demonstration as 'marvellous'.
item.content:encoded:
The Queen joined the Duchess of Cornwall to see the remarkable work of the country’s cancer-detecting dogs first hand today – and got more of a demonstration than she bargained for.

For as well as being trained to use their extraordinary sense of smell to locate early-stage disease, some of the incredible canines have also been taught to alert their owners to potentially life-threatening conditions such as epilepsy and diabetes.

Mid-way through the display of their work at the Royal Mews, a talented four-year-old Labrador/Golden Retriever cross called Nimbus realised that his owner, Jodie Griffin, who suffers from a rare condition that causes her to falls unconscious several times a day, was about to have an episode.

As the monarch looked on, Nimbus jumped up to warn Jodie, 28, and helped shepherd her to a safe place so she could lie down.

The Queen said afterwards that the demonstration had been ‘marvellous’ and ‘fascinating’.

‘I can imagine that it must be difficult to get enough dogs,’ she added, and smiled to learn that a number of rescue dogs and failed gun dogs had been trained up.

Speaking to another dog owner, the 92-year-old monarch commented: 'He is clearly very clever. I can imagine that you can’t imagine life without him.’ 

Scroll down for video  

After she had recovered, pet portrait painter Jodie from Cannock, Staffordshire, told the Queen how Nimbus had transformed her life she got him.

‘It’s very clever and you must have a very good relationship with him,’ the monarch said.

‘He’s my best friend,’ Jodie, who suffers from Postural Orthostatic Tachycardia Syndrome, known as PoTS, admitted.

She later explained that the charity responsible for training and matching her up with Nimbus – Medical Detection Dogs - hadn’t been sure, initially, that it could work as their dogs sense there is a problem based on odour. 

Jodie’s blackouts are caused by her body’s inability to pump sufficient oxygenated blood to the brain, causing her regularly fall unconscious.

But using saliva and sweat samples from Jodie, they were, incredibly, able to train Nimbus to pick up on signs that she is about to fall ill that would be otherwise imperceptible to humans.

‘Having Nimbus has just transformed my life she,’ she said.

‘I can be affected up to two or three times a day and had been too scared to go out in case I hurt myself. He has changed everything. What he and the charity do is just amazing.’

Medical Detection Dogs was founded by CEO Dr Claire Guest, a scientist and animal behaviour expert, ten years ago. 

She is herself in remission from breast cancer after her own dog, Daisy, who sadly died in February this year, detected the disease by nudging her repeatedly in the chest.

‘From that time on I believed that dogs could detect cancer,’ she said.

She has since discovered through rigorous clinical trials that cancer has its own ‘unique’ odour and that dogs, with their incredible sense of smell, are able to detect it.

For example, a canine would be able to sniff out one single teaspoon of sugar in two Olympic-sized swimming pools – and their power of cognitive thinking allows them to even recognise strains of cancer they haven’t come across before.

Dr Guest has since made it her life’s work to train specialist bio detection dogs to identify the odour of human disease using urine, breath and sweat samples.

In clinical trials, the dogs have proved to have up to a 93 per cent reliability for detecting prostate cancer, for example.

Early diagnosis can save lives and allow for less invasive testing and treatment, the charity says.

It is now branching out, testing the ability of dogs to recognise early Parkinson’s and malaria.

‘Dogs are basically bio sensors with a fluffy coat and a waggy tail,’ Dr Guest explained today to the Queen.

‘He has an incredible nose, he has 300 million sensory receptors. Us humans have five million.’

The Duchess of Cornwall was certainly impressed by their work and became the charity’s patron in 2008, before setting up today’s 10th anniversary event.

She introduced her mother-in-law to their work with demonstrations by nine-year-old cocker spaniel Kizzy, a cancer detection dog, and black Labrador Peanut, three, a Parkinson’s detection dog, who both successfully identified several samples out of a string of placebos.

She said: ‘One in two of us will now be diagnosed with cancer in the course of our lifetimes. Early detection is crucial to successful medical treatment. It is more important than ever that we develop an easy and reliable test to rocket-boost survival rates.

‘I am hugely grateful to the Duchess of Cornwall and to the Queen in helping us to raise awareness of our charity so that our vital research can soon be put into practical use in saving lives.’

The Queen also met Magic, whose sense of smell is so acute that he can detect even the most minute changes in his owner’s blood sugar levels when she is upstairs in the bath and he is asleep in his basket downstairs.

Claire Pesterfield, 45, from Hitchen, Hertfordshire, who has had Type 1 Diabetes since she was a teenager, says that in five years Magic has warned her of danger more than 4,500 times.

‘He has literally saved my life,’ she said.

Britain is such a world leader in terms of the dogs that it has recently teamed up with physicist Dr Andreas Mershin from the prestigious Massachusetts Institute of Technology to develop a ‘digital nose’ that can also sniff out cancer calls with the help of the latest AI technology.
item.dc:abstract: The Queen (pictured left with Camilla, during the demonstration, and right, with arriving at the event) attended an event to mark the 10th birthday of the Medical Detection Dogs charity at the Royal Mews in London. After watching a dog demonstration by the charity, she commented that it was 'marvellous' and 'fascinating'. She also met with owners and their dogs (inset) during the event. The 92-year-old monarch was joined by Camilla, 70, who is patron of the dog charity at the event.
item.dc:creator: Emily Chan
item.mi:shortTitle: Queen meets hero medical dogs and she looks delighted

item.title: Victoria Beckham's make-up artist reveals the five simple tweaks that have taken YEARS off the star's face - and how she plumped her pout without injections
item.description: Make-up artist Wendy Rowe has given Victoria plumper lips by using just a pencil and gloss and ditched contouring in favour of more natural make-up for a fresher, younger look.
item.content:encoded:
Victoria Beckham's make-up artist has revealed the five simple tweaks she's made to the designer's beauty look to take years off her face. 

Make-up artist Wendy Rowe told Byrdie how she's given Victoria plumper lips by using just a pencil and gloss and ditched contouring in favour of more natural make-up for a fresher, younger look. 

Recent snaps of the former Spice Girls star, 44, show the mother-of-four looking flawless, with a plump pout and a natural glow. 

But in pictures from the 2014 Met Ball heavier eyeliner and countouring created a harsher look that actually made Victoria look older than her years.

Read on to find out the easy tricks that could also take years off your face.  

LIPS 

Victoria's lips are looking fuller these days, but it's nothing to do with injectables.  

A pared-back matte nude has always been Victoria's go-to, but she's now subtly overlining her lips to make them look plumper. 

Wendy uses Burberry Lip Colour Contour to create the same 'polished feeling' of a lipstick, but is so natural it blends in and doesn't look like you're wearing lippy.  

A slick of gloss on the top lip also adds to the bee-stung look.  

BROWS 

A straight brow used to be Victoria's preference, but now she's opted for a very subtle arch. 

This opens up her eyes and softens her features for an anti-ageing effect.  

EYE MAKE-UP 

While Victoria is sticking with her signature smokey eye, she's using a pared down version. 

'We do dark kohl around the base of the lash [line], keeping the eyelid quite open and then do several coats of mascara for super-long, voluminous lashes,' Rowe explained. 

'I also use a beige eyeliner to widen the eye.'

FOUNDATION

It's out with the heavy contouring and in with the natural look. 

Wendy is using a luminous base in the form of Burberry Fresh Glow Luminous Fluid Base and Burberry Cashmere Concealer and blusher to create a fresh glow. 

SKINCARE 

Victoria also fuels her natural glow with Sarah Champman's  £145 Radiance Recharge System - a 10 day programme of active skincare shots.

One days one, three, and nine you use a Lactic Micropeel to resurface, smoothe and brighten the skin. 

Days two, five and seven contain high doses of potent antioxidant vitamin C to boost skin clarity and luminosity.

On day 10 a hyaluronic formula visibly plumps and restores a radiant glow.
item.dc:abstract: Make-up artist Wendy Rowe has given Victoria plumper lips by using just a pencil and gloss and ditched contouring in favour of more natural make-up for a fresher, younger look. Left: sporting a fresher, natural look and right a the Met Ball in 2014 with heavy eye-makeup, contoured cheeks and straight brows.
item.dc:creator: Siofra Brennan
item.mi:shortTitle: How Victoria Beckham took years off her face with five simple tweaks

item.title: Aldi introduces two new products to its Jo Malone-inspired collection – and they're already selling for THREE times the price on eBay
item.description: The supermarket recently giant launched its Luxury Hand and Body Wash and Luxury Hand and Body Lotion - both £2.99 for 250ml - and they are already being flogged on eBay.
item.content:encoded:
They have already won over beauty fans with copycat versions of high-end Jo Malone products.

And now Aldi has expanded its budget beauty offering with two new skincare products inspired by the British luxury brand - and they're already proving a hit with shoppers.

The supermarket giant launched its Luxury Hand and Body Wash and Luxury Hand and Body Lotion, both £2.99 for 250ml, in May.

They are modelled on Jo Malone's 'premium equivalent' products, a £40 Pomegranate Noir Body & Hand Lotion and a £30 Body Wash - each costing more than ten times the price of Aldi's copycats. 

Scroll down for video 

Now savvy customers are flogging them on eBay for a profit, with some listed at three times the price of Aldi's RRP.

Some were being sold in sets of four priced at £15 to £20, equivalent to almost twice the price of the in-store offering.

While one eBay seller was flogging a single bottle of the body wash for £9.25 - more than three times the RRP. 

Aldi's hugely popular Luxury Collection, inspired by Jo Malone, now consists of five products, including candles, reed diffusers, room sprays as well as the new hand and body washes and lotions.

The German chain has also won plaudits for its Lacura beauty range, including a Garnier-inspired sheet mask and a makeup sponge modelled on the cult favourite Beautyblender. 

Due to the popularity of the range, products often crop up on eBay with sellers - dubbed 'fashion flippers' - flogging them at more than double the original price as shoppers scramble to get their hands on them. 

But last year Jo Malone hit back at the ‘creative laziness’ of budget retailers who continue to launch copycat versions of her trademark products.

When asked how she felt about high street and supermarket brands copying her perfumes, candles and diffusers, Malone said: ‘You have to really protect yourself, that’s where the lawyers come in.

'I think people that mimic, it’s laziness - laziness instead of creativity because they can’t come up with it themselves.’

Asked if she thought imitation is the sincerest form of flattery, Miss Malone told Chiswick Book Festival: ‘No I think it’s creative laziness. They haven’t copied Jo Loves (her new company) yet.' 

Aldi is not the first brand to try its hand at designer dupes; earlier this year, Lidl unveiled a £3.49 anti-ageing potion to rival La Prairie's £494 cellular radiance cream.

From Primark's much-hyped nude eye shadow palettes to Superdrug's £3 body mists, many fans have been impressed by the calibre of some of these cut-price copycats, often taking to sites like Reddit to rave about the products on line.
item.dc:abstract: The supermarket recently giant launched its Luxury Hand and Body Wash and Luxury Hand and Body Lotion (right) - both £2.99 for 250ml - and they are already being flogged on eBay. They are modelled on Jo Malone's 'premium equivalent' products, a £40 Pomegranate Noir Body & Hand Lotion (left) and a £30 Body Wash - each costing more than ten times the price of Aldi's copycats.
item.dc:creator: Unity Blott
item.mi:shortTitle: Aldi expands its Jo Malone-inspired luxury skincare range

item.title: Buckingham Palace shares vintage photograph revealing how its traditional summer garden parties looked 120 years ago
item.description: The black-and-white photograph shared by Buckingham Palace shows guests wearing top hats, tails and extravagant floor-length gowns as they attended a party in the palace grounds in 1897.
item.content:encoded:
Buckingham Palace has shared a vintage photograph revealing how its traditional summer garden parties looked 120 years ago. 

The black-and-white photograph shows guests wearing top hats, tails and extravagant floor-length gowns as they attended a party in the palace grounds in 1897.

Aside from the fashion though, not much else appears to have changed when it comes to the annual garden parties. 

Queen Victoria was the one who began the tradition, with Buckingham Palace summer parties going all the way back to the 1860s.

Sharing the vintage photograph on the royal family's official Twitter account, Buckingham Palace said: '[Did you know] that Garden Parties first began in the 1860s? 

'This photograph, from [the Royal Collection Trust], shows a Garden Party from 1897 compared with today's.'

Below the photograph, the Palace shared a colour photograph from yesterday's event, which was presided over by Prince Charles.

Nowadays, the dress code for male guests is morning coats or lounge suits, while women wear day dress, usually with hats or fascinators. 

Guests can also choose to wear National dress or uniform at Buckingham Palace Garden Parties.

However, back in the day, all male guests can be seen wearing top hats and tails, while the women wore sweeping gowns.  

Today, the Queen hosts three garden parties at Buckingham Palace and one at Holyrood Palace, her Scottish residence. 

More than 30,000 members of the public, who have been invited because of the impact they have on their community, attend every year. 

Along with the Queen, other members of the royal family also attend, with Prince Charles, the Duchess of Cornwall, Princess Anne, Prince William and Princess Eugenie all making appearances this year.

Buckingham Palace previously shared a black-and-white photograph of a garden party in 1947, which features ex-serviceman playing cricket on the lawn.
item.dc:abstract: The black-and-white photograph (top) shared by Buckingham Palace shows guests wearing top hats, tails and extravagant floor-length gowns as they attended a party in the palace grounds in 1897. The shot was shared alongside a colour picture taken at yesterday's garden party (bottom), which was presided over by Prince Charles. Queen Victoria was the one who began the tradition of hosting garden parties, which go all the way back to the 1860s.
item.dc:creator: Emily Chan
item.mi:shortTitle: Buckingham Palace shares picture showing how garden party looked

item.title: Happy National Day, Sweden! Crown Princess Victoria dazzles in Self Portrait as the royals celebrate in Stockholm – after sharing an adorable portrait of Estelle and Oscar to mark the occasion
item.description: The Swedish royal family is attending National Day Celebrations across Stockholm on Wednesday. Crown Princess Victoria and Prince Daniel visited Stromsholm Castle this morning.
item.content:encoded:
Crown Princess Victoria proved she is truly in the fashion fold as she stepped out for Sweden's National Day celebrations on Wednesday.

The 40-year-old royal looked her elegant best in a white dress by Self Portrait - a brand favoured by other royals including Kate and Meghan.

The mother-of-two proved why the affordable designer is so popular with the broderie anglaise gown cutting a flattering finish.  

She kept her accessories to a minimum in the form of a taupe court shoe as she joined her husband Prince Daniel at Stromsholm Castle this morning.  

Meanwhile Victoria's parents King Carl Gustaf and Queen Silvia attended National Day celebrations at the Open Palace, Royal Palace of Stockholm.

Silvia, 74, arrived in traditional Swedish dress of blue and yellow dress embroidered with daisies as is custom on the national holiday.

To further mark the occasion  the royal court released an adorable new portrait of two-year-old Prince Oscar and Princess Estelle, six, on Instagram earlier today.

Estelle sported a blue and yellow dress embroidered with daisies, teamed with a wide collared white shirt and wore her hair in a low ponytail.

Meanwhile her younger brother is adorable in a pair of black shorts and a white shirt.

Every year the King and Queen take part in a ceremony at Skansen, Stockholm’s open-air museum, where the yellow and blue Swedish flag is run up the mast, and children in traditional peasant costume present the royals with bouquets of summer flowers.

National Day also now recognises new Swedish citizens, welcoming them with special ceremonies held around the country.

Not normally known for being the most patriotic nation, National Day has been embraced over recent years, with some groups even pushing for the country to have a national dish, according to the country’s official website.

National Day is an annual celebration held in honour of two historical events: on 6 June 1523, Gustav Vasa was elected king and, on the same date in 1809, the country adopted a new constitution. It became a public holiday in 2004.

This is not the first time we have seen Victoria in the elegant dress having selected it for the christening of Prince Oscar in 2016.

Self Portrait has become a staple brand among royals and celebrities alike starting at around £165 for its shirts and blouses, and going up to £400 for its famous 'naked' sheer maxi dresses.

The buzz around the label, which is just three years old, grew to a point in the summer 2017 where Selfridges was selling 100 Self-Portrait pieces a week.

The Duchess of Cambridge sent the brand's profile stratospheric when she wore a white lace dress to the world premiere of A Street Cat Named Bob in 2016.

Since then the new Duchess of Sussex has also embraced the label wearing a green pleated dress by the brand ahead of her wedding in April.

It has also been seen on the likes of Princess Beatrice and Kate's sister Pippa Matthews.
item.dc:abstract: The Swedish royal family is attending National Day Celebrations across Stockholm on Wednesday. Crown Princess Victoria (left) and Prince Daniel visited Stromsholm Castle this morning meanwhile King Carl Gustaf and Queen Silvia (right0attended National Day celebrations at the Open Palace, Royal Palace of Stockholm. To further mark the occasion the royal court released an adorable new portrait of two-year-old Prince Oscar and Princess Estelle (inset), six, on Instagram earlier today.
item.dc:creator: Martha Cliff
item.mi:shortTitle: Swedish royal family celebrate National Day in Stockholm

item.title: I wanna dance with somebody! Video captures the heartwarming moment carers join a woman with dementia, 67, as she boogies to Whitney Houston at her nursing home
item.description: Kathleen Preston, 67, was caught on camera bopping along to Whitney Houston's How Will I Know at the Ashlynn Grange Care Home in Peterborough this week.
item.content:encoded:
This heartwarming video captures the moment carers joined in with a woman with dementia as she danced to Whitney Houston in her nursing home.    

Kathleen Preston, 67, was caught on camera bopping along to Whitney Houston's How Will I Know as the music video played on a television at the Ashlynn Grange Care Home in Peterborough this week.

She can be seen smiling and moving to the music, before four members of staff join in the fun.  

One carer even affectionately takes Kathleen by the hand and twirls are around as the music plays.  

Kathleen's daughter Teri Preston said she had discovered a love of dance since moving into the home in February, and that the carers 'think the world' of her mother. 

Delighted Kathleen can be seen exclaiming: 'I can't stop!' as she dances around the sitting room. 

Teri, 45, said of the feel-good footage: 'My heart melted when I saw the video of my mum dancing.

'Then, when I saw the members of staff join in with her, it made me well up.

'Mum has suffered with dementia for many years, and knowing she is being cared for so well really gives me peace of mind.'

Kathleen's memory started to deteriorate in 2007, after her husband, Roy, died from emphysema aged 60.

After his death, the former catering assistant began experiencing hallucinations and was often forgetful.

Daughter Teri, a volunteer for the British Red Cross, explained: 'I first noticed something was wrong with mum's memory when she started to forget where she'd left her keys and would think she'd eaten, when she hadn't.

'It soon got worse, and I discovered she was wondering out the house without clothes on and crying in distress all the time.

'It was heartbreaking to watch. Thankfully, she still remembers I'm her daughter.'

Eventually, Kathleen was diagnosed with dementia and moved into the home in February of this year.

Teri, who lives with partner, Michael Powell, 46, a roofer, visits her mum three times a week.

The mum-of-three, of Wisbech in Cambridgeshire, said: 'Since being in the home, mum has found a love of dance.

'Whenever music is played she gets up and bops along - the staff are so sweet they even turn the volume up for her.

'She loves the carers and they think the world of her.'

Teri added: 'There is a stigma surrounding care homes and I want people to know that there are good places that exist, places that really care about the welfare of their residents.

'At my mum's home they're always throwing parties and putting on entertainment. I cannot fault the care.

'I want to thank the staff for all they do for my mum. Carers don't get enough praise for what they do.

'I'll be forever grateful to them for making mum happy in her final years.'

Mandy Jackson, operations director at the care home, added: 'At Athena Care Homes our greatest reward is to see our residents smiling and living life to the full.

'We value each and every one of our wonderful team members who consistently go above and beyond, to ensure that the residents in their care are happy and content in safe and comfortable surroundings.'
item.dc:abstract: Kathleen Preston, 67, was caught on camera bopping along to Whitney Houston's How Will I Know as the music video played on a television at the Ashlynn Grange Care Home in Peterborough this week. She can be seen smiling and moving to the music, before four members of staff join in the fun.
item.dc:creator: Kerry Mcdermott
item.mi:shortTitle: Video captures carers joining dementia fighter, 67, for dance

item.title: Handbags from Kate Spade’s Frances Valentine brand SELL OUT following the designer’s tragic death – despite never achieving the same success as the eponymous label she sold
item.description: At the time of writing, every bag from Spade's accessories label - launched in 2016 - was listed as out of stock on the brand's website (francesvalentine.com).
item.content:encoded:
News of Kate Spade's untimely death sent shock waves throughout the fashion world.

And it seems fans are desperate for a lasting memento of the late designer, with handbags from her Frances Valentine range selling out almost instantly.

At the time of writing, every handbag from Spade's accessories label - launched in 2016 - was listed as out of stock on the brand's website (francesvalentine.com).

Sold-out designs include a $375 (£279) vachetta leather shoulder tote, a $295 (£219) wicker crossbody and a $245 (£182) canvas shopping tote.

Even a $28 (£21) canvas wine bag, a $35 (£26) pair of earrings and a $58 (£43) household valet tray had sold out in addition to sunglasses, wallets and makeup cases.

Scroll down for video 

Spade, who died at home in New York this week aged 55, set up Frances Valentine, named after her daughter, with her husband Andy after selling shares of her first fashion venture, Kate Spade & Co.

It was bought in 2017 for $2.4billion (around £1.7million) - 20 times the value the company held when its founders sold their shares - by Coach's parent company, Tapestry.

Frances Valentine, which has never publicly disclosed its turnover or profits, failed to achieve the same success as Spade's eponymous brand, despite positive reviews from fashion magazines and critics.

It has no standalone NYC store but sells its items online on its own website and is stocked in Bloomingdales, Saks and Nordstrom.  

Spade was found dead in her apartment in New York City on Tuesday following a suspected suicide but her death is an ongoing investigation, law enforcement officials have said. 

The businesswoman was best known for the eponymous handbag brand she founded with her husband in 1993. 

Born Katherine Noel Brosnahan, Spade gained a degree in journalism from Arizona State University in 1985 before moving to New York to join Mademoiselle magazine as a fashion editor the following year.

She launched her career as a handbag designer with her husband in the early 1990s following her departure from the magazine, and opened her first store in 1996.

The brand has since become a household name with stores around the world and an expanded product line including clothing, footwear and stationery.

Her line won acclaim early on, with Spade winning the award for America’s New Fashion Talent in Accessories from the Council of Fashion Designers of America in 1996. 

Spade completed the sale of her share of the business in 2006 for $124 million (£93 million), and left in 2007, taking time off for charity work and to look after her daughter, Frances Beatrix, born in 2005.

More recently, she was inducted into the Entrepreneur Hall of Fame at the Henry W Bloch School of Management in the US, and business magazine Fast Company named her one of its Most Creative People in Business last year.

In 2016, the designer and her husband teamed up again to launch handbag and footwear brand Frances Valentine.

She also changed her last name to Valentine to distinguish her from her original brand, she told publication Business Of Fashion that year.
item.dc:abstract: At the time of writing, every bag from the Frances Valentine accessories label - launched in 2016 by Kate Spade (left) - was listed as out of stock on the brand's website. Sold-out designs include a $375 (£279) vachetta leather shoulder tote, a $295 (£219) wicker crossbody, a $245 (£182) bucket bag, top right, and a $245 (£182) canvas shopping tote, bottom right.
item.dc:creator: Unity Blott
item.mi:shortTitle: Kate Spade's Frances Valentine label sells out following her death

link.title: Kate Spade's lasting legacy: The legion of stars, including Reese Witherspoon, Taylor Swift, and Drew Barrymore, who have proudly worn the late designer's namesake brand over the years
Duchess of Cambridge and her sister Pippa have worn Kate Spade dresses bearing late designer's name - after she sold the label in 2006
Frances Valentine

item.title: 'Saving up for one of your purses taught me independence': Fashion fans share emotional stories of their FIRST Kate Spade handbags following the designer's suicide
item.description: Thousands of women have been sharing photos of their first Kate Spade handbags - and emotional stories following the suicide of the 55-year-old designer in New York on Tuesday.
item.content:encoded:
Fans of Kate Spade, who was found dead in her apartment on Tuesday, have been paying tribute to the fashion designer by posting photos of the first Kate Spade handbags they owned.

Thousands of women - including a raft of celebrities - are sharing the snaps on social media, along with often emotional stories attached, as to how they came to own their first high-end bag.

Many said the designer had inspired them to work hard so they could afford to buy her work, with one saying she 'visited' a bag frequently in a department store until she had saved up enough money from her summer job to actually buy it. 

Spade, 55, committed suicide in her Park Avenue home on Tuesday morning, leaving a heartbreaking suicide note addressed to her teenage daughter, telling her: 'I have always loved you.'

Scroll down for video 

Touching anecdotes from fans of the brand, which Spade began selling off in 1999, have been filling social media since the news of her death was announced.

@MetalBlonde tweeted: 'The first designer purse I ever saved up for and bought from a 'fancy store' was yours. Your designs were whimsical, retro, and magical.'    

@juliaccarpenter shared a snap of a distinctive of Spade's famous typewriter bag, saying: 'For pretty much all of high school, I fantasized about a future in which I carried the Kate Spade "all typed up clyde" satchel to my fancy NYC writer job. 

'Saw a girl on the subway just last month holding one and we shared a giant smile.' 

For others, buying a bag by the designer signalled a coming of age. @travelwithkatie wrote: 'I got my first #KateSpade bag when I graduated college. Receiving it made me feel like a grown, professional woman ready to take on life in an effortlessly chic powerful way.' 

@theconnectedk felt similarly, penning: 'When I was a young girl, getting a #katespade bag was THE biggest deal. I’ll never forget my first one - multicolored, watercolor stripes - It was the old 90’s boxy design and I felt amazing holding it. That’s what Kate did, she made women feel amazing. Thank you Kate & RIP.' 

Writer Melanie Hauser, who writes as Melanie Benjamin, revealed that she felt a Kate Spade bag was aspirational.

She wrote that she had promised herself that if she ever had a New York Times Bestseller, she'd buy one.

She tweeted: 'True story: One of my dreams was to own a #KateSpade handbag & I vowed that if I ever made the NY Times Best Seller List, I would buy one. When AVIATOR'S WIFE made the list, I did - here's the photo I sent to my editor when I bought it.' 

Fans young and old have been tweeting snaps of their first bags, with 14-year-old actress Peyton Kennedy revealing that she was so obsessed with the designer, her parents threw her a Kate Spade-themed 13th birthday party. 

Another, @maydaymindy9, revealed that she was saving the Kate Spade diaper bag she'd used with her own children to pass onto them when they get pregnant, because the roomy nylon bag had stood the test of time. 

Spade, who had worked in the magazine industry as accessories editor for Mademoiselle in the late 80s, saw a gap in the market and throughout the 90s, her bold, colorful designs and whimsical prints became a solid hit among New York City's glitterati.

Thanks to the brand's popularity among celebrities like Gwyneth Paltrow and Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen, its sales grew and in 1998, revenues reached $27million.

Confident about its future but keen to work on other ventures, Kate and her husband, along with their founding partner Elyce Arons, sold 56 per cent of their shares to Neiman Marcus for $34million in 1999. 

They retained 44 per cent for the next seven years until they finally cashed out in 2007 to raise their daughter.  They sold their remaining shares for $59million.
item.dc:abstract: Thousands of Kate Spade fans have been sharing photos of their first handbags following the suicide of the 55-year-old designer in New York on Tuesday. Alongside many of the images are emotional stories from women who say they were inspired to work hard so they could buy the designer's work. (Pictured: Women on Twitter sharing photos of their first Kate Spade bags including writer Melanie Benjamin, top left, and young actress Peyton Kennedy, bottom, centre)
item.dc:creator: Joanna Tweedy
item.mi:shortTitle: Fans share first Kate Spade bag they owned after designer's suicide

item.title: Miss Great Britain DEFENDS pageant swimsuit rounds after they were scrapped by the Miss America contest - and insists she won her crown because of her charity work
item.description: Speaking on GMB, Saffron Hart, who is the current Miss Great Britain, said she wasn't the most beautiful woman in her year but won because she runs her own businesses and does charity work.
item.content:encoded:
The current Miss Great Britain has defended beauty pageant swimsuit rounds after it was announced they are to be ditched from the Miss America contest. 

Saffron Hart appeared on Good Morning Britain on Wednesday, following the announcement that the famous bikini round will no longer feature in the US pageant, whose organisers have said contestants will not be judged on their 'physical appearance' going forward.  

But Saffron insisted that she and her rivals were judged as a 'package', and that she was crowned Miss Great Britain because of her charity work and business accomplishments.    

The beauty queen, who appeared on the show in her crown and sash, said the swimsuit rounds are her favourite and about fun - not women being judged on their attractiveness.

She said: 'You're completely you and it's just the judges. This is me, you take me as I am. It's just a fun round. There's nothing in the judging criteria for the bikini round that says figure or their body or anything like that.' 

Saffron said she wasn't the most beautiful woman in the pageant, but won because she runs her own businesses and does charity work.

'I definitely was not the most beautiful girl on the night, the other girls were absolutely stunning. We all had different qualities, but it went on the package. I'm a business woman, I've got two businesses, I do a lot of work for charities, I work with self-development mindset in schools.' 

Also on the show via video link was Mallory Hagan, who was Miss America 2013, who compared the pageants to 'scholarships' due to the opportunities they offer women competing, and said winning a crown amounted to a 365 day a year job of charity work. 

But viewers welcomed news that bikini rounds could soon be a thing of the past, with many branding pageants 'backwards.   

She has just been announced as the Democrat candidate for congress in her home state Alabama, and agreed with Saffron that pageant entrants are judged on personality.

She said: 'What a lot of people don't realise is the job of Miss America is 365 days a year of public speaking, being a national ambassador for children's network, hospitals and for your personal platform, mine had to do with child sexual abuse prevention. 

'Going into Miss America you have a ten-minute long press conference style interview and that is where Miss America is won.'

Viewers disagreed that the pageants aren't about beauty, saying less conventionally attractive women would never win.

One tweeted: 'I beauty contests were based on interlect you would not look at women. They would listen to their voices. It is not a who's got the sexiest voice competition.'

Another posted: 'Does anyone else feel like they were just watching Miss Congeniality? ''it is not a beauty pageant, it is a scholarship programme.'''

'Would miss Great Britain get a second look without being in a bikini though?' a third said.

Another said: 'I can’t believe we still have beauty pageants. Are we going backwards?' 

Yesterday Gretchen Carlson, the new head of Miss America's board of directors, revealed that Miss America will no longer judge women based on their physical appearance. 

Instead contestants will be asked to wear any attire that makes them feel confident, expresses their personal style, and shows how they will advance the role of Miss America.

'We've heard from a lot of young woman who say, "We'd love to be a part of your program but we don't want to be out there in high heels and a swimsuit"', Carlson said.

'So guess what, you don't have to do that anymore.'
item.dc:abstract: Miss Great Britain Saffron Hart insisted that she and her rivals were judged as a 'package', and that she was crowned because of her charity work and business accomplishments. The beauty queen from Hull (seen left on the show and right before her win), who appeared on the show in her crown and sash, said the swimsuit rounds are her favourite and about fun - not women being judged on their attractiveness. But not all viewers were convinced (tweets inset).
item.dc:creator: Kerry Mcdermott
item.mi:shortTitle: Beauty queens say winning pageants is about personality and not looks

item.title: The moment we’ve been waiting for! Harry and Meghan to make their first Buckingham Palace balcony appearance when they join the royal family for Trooping the Colour on Saturday
item.description: Prince Harry and Meghan are expected to join the Queen and other members of the royal family for the military parade in London. It will be their first appearance since their honeymoon.
item.content:encoded:
Prince Harry and Meghan are set to make their first balcony appearance together at Buckingham Palace for Trooping the Colour on Saturday.

The newlyweds are expected to join the Queen and other members of the royal family for the military parade, held in honour of the Queen's birthday.

This will be the new Duke and Duchess of Sussex's first public appearance since their honeymoon. 

Unlike the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge, Harry, 33, and Meghan, 36, did not share a traditional kiss on the Buckingham Palace balcony on the big day after choosing Windsor as their venue.

A royal source told the Mirror: 'There will be huge interest in seeing the newlyweds after the magic of their wedding.

'The balcony appearance is the perfect symbol of how Meghan has been welcomed into the family.' 

Harry attends the Trooping the Colour ceremony annually, but this will his new wife's first appearance at the traditional parade. 

There had been much speculation over whether Harry and Meghan would share a kiss outside St George's Chapel ahead of their wedding.

Prince Charles and Diana began the tradition of sharing a kiss on the Buckingham Palace balcony after their wedding in 1981.

Prince Andrew and Sarah Ferguson followed suit in 1986, with Kate and William carrying on the tradition in 2011. 

Harry and Meghan have not been seen in public since attending Prince Charles's 70th birthday celebrations at Buckingham Palace just three days after their wedding.

They are believed to be on their honeymoon, with reports suggesting they had chosen the Fairmont Jasper Park Lodge in Canada as their destination.

Earlier this week, it was announced that Meghan would be conducting her first joint engagements with the Queen in Cheshire next week.

In an unprecedented move, the Duchess of Sussex will be travelling with the head of state on the royal train.

Only the most senior members of the Royal Family – namely the Queen, Prince Philip, Prince Charles and the Duchess of Cornwall - are entitled to use it. 

Harry, Kate and William are not believed to have ever used it in an official capacity.

Trooping the Colour is attended by senior members of the royal family including Prince Charles, the Duchess of Cornwall and the Duke and Duchess of Sussex.

It is not clear if Prince Louis, who is just six weeks old, will join his parents at Buckingham Palace, although Prince George and Princess Charlotte are expected to attend, as in previous years.
item.dc:abstract: Prince Harry and Meghan (left, on their wedding day) are expected to join the Queen and other members of the royal family (right, at last year's Trooping the Colour) for the military parade in London. This will be the new Duke and Duchess of Sussex's first public appearance since their honeymoon. Unlike the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge, Harry, 33, and Meghan, 36, did not share a traditional kiss on the Buckingham Palace balcony on the big day after choosing Windsor as their venue.
item.dc:creator: Emily Chan
item.mi:shortTitle: Harry and Meghan to make first Buckingham Palace balcony appearance

item.title: 'Sandwich Cream sounds borderline evil!' Salad Cream fans up in arms after Millennials kill 100-year-old brand
item.description: Shoppers have taken to Twitter to vent their frustrations following the news that Heinz plans to rebrand Salad Cream to Sandwich Cream after 104 years on the market.
item.content:encoded:
Heinz announced yesterday that it plans to rename Salad Cream, Sandwich Cream after 104 years to 'fairly represent' how people use it. 

However, shoppers are less than happy about the change of name taking to Twitter to share their outrage over the 'borderline evil' decision.

Many argued that there was no logic in renaming the product based on how customers used it, and made their own cheeky suggestions for rebranding.

One wrote: 'Just because salad cream is not used for salads. I don't put tomato sauce on my tomatoes either better rename that too.'

Others said that while they were prepared to accept some rebranding this was a step too far.

'I said nothing when they changed Marathon to Snickers, even Opal Fruits becoming Starburst but this is just a a step too far... lettuce keep salad cream' fumed one.

Another added: 'What fresh hell is this?! I wouldn't dream of putting salad cream in a sandwich but I love it on a side salad especially with an omelette.'

Some were inclined to blame the younger generation with one tweeting: 'To add to the long list of things Millennials have killed: HEINZ SALAD CREAM'.  

The condiment has been called Salad Cream for 104 years but Heinz announced yesterday that it is set to ditch the iconic name of the zingy white sauce because it no longer 'fairly represents' how most people actually use it.

Only 14 per cent of buyer's dress salads with the sauce, according to Heinz, as it's now much more popular to use it as an accompaniment to tuna, ham or cheese in sandwiches as an alternative to mayonnaise.

The news could trouble some traditionalists who rallied to save the brand from extinction nearly 20 years ago. 

Parent group Kraft Heinz said it is working with brand design specialists Jones Knowles Ritchie on overhauling one of Britain's longest running kitchen staples, which launched in 1914.

A spokesman for Heinz told trade journal The Grocer the name no longer 'fairly represents the product's ingredients or usage occasions'.

Its own research discovered just 14 per cent used the cream on salad with other popular uses now being as an accompaniment to tuna, ham or cheese in sandwiches, usually as an alternative to mayonnaise.

According to The Grocer, it is considering the name 'Sandwich Cream' to represent its appeal to 'younger shoppers.' 

UK sales of the brand dipped 5.4 per cent to £28.8 million last year.

The Heinz spokesman added: 'As a market leading business, Kraft Heinz continues to audit its portfolio in order to meet the needs of consumers.

'There are consumers now who haven't grown up with the brand in the household and just don't know about the iconic zingy flavour or what to eat it with.'

The consultation process means the earliest a new name will be introduced is in September.

In 1999, it was revealed that Heinz were about to ditch the brand but once the leak was published it led to a major protest by shoppers and it saved the brand.

The publicity helped sales and Heinz took advantage by relaunching Salad Cream in new-look packs and putting the price up.
item.dc:abstract: Shoppers have taken to Twitter to vent their frustrations following the news that Heinz plans to rebrand Salad Cream to Sandwich Cream after 104 years on the market. Many argued that there was no logic in renaming the product based on how customers used it, and made their own cheeky suggestions for rebranding. Others said that while they were prepared to accept some rebranding this was a step too far.
item.dc:creator: Martha Cliff
item.mi:shortTitle: Salad Cream fans up in arms over Heinz’s plans to rebrand

item.title: Judy Murray reveals the indoor games she invented to help her tennis star sons Andy and Jamie improve their skills as children - and all you need is a cereal box, a biscuit tin and balloons
item.description: EXCLUSIVE: Judy Murray, 58, told how she helped tennis aces Andy, 31, and Jamie, 32, learn the basics of the sport through simple indoor games that used household objects.
item.content:encoded:
Tennis star brothers Andy and Jamie Murray train at world-class facilities with the very best coaches in the business.

But their mother Judy, 58, has revealed her sons began their tennis careers with rather more modest practice sessions.

The tennis coach told FEMAIL how she helped Grand Slam winners Andy, 31, and Jamie, 32, learn the basics of the sport through simple indoor games that used nothing more than a cereal box, biscuit tins and a packet of balloons. 

The mother-of-two explained she invented the games as a way to keep her sons occupied at the family home in Dunblane when they were growing up.

'I learned loads just from chucking things at my kids,' she said. '[I had] two kids, 15 months apart. Terrible weather in Scotland. No money. So I actually became very inventive.'

Judy, a coach with nearly 30 years' experience, began coaching children at the local tennis club before later turning her attention to her two sons.

She recalled how Jamie, a five-time Grand Slam doubles winner, and Wimbledon champion Andy had their first rally not with a racket and ball - but with a balloon in the living room.   

Judy said: 'My kids probably had their first rally with a balloon across the sofa. 

Judy Murray's games

Balloon tennis

'[Jamie and Andy] probably had their first rally with a balloon across the sofa. A balloon doesn't break any windows, costs next to nothing and is big and slow so anyone can hit it.

'And then once you can pass one balloon back and forward, try keep two balloons going at the same time. 

'Try putting one hand behind your back - so in effect you're sort of doing a backhand, or hit one with your hand and one with your foot.' 

Cereal box table tennis 

'[All they needed was] two biscuit tin lids and a ping pong ball. A ping pong ball was the only thing I needed to pay for, which would be 20p from the newsagent's.

'What I realised watching them was that in order to control the ball, their hands had to be out in front and that's actually what tennis is all about - hitting the ball in front of you.'

When Judy needed the kitchen table back the brothers moved onto the floor, forcing them to be more mobile with their hands. 

'A balloon doesn't break any windows, costs next to nothing and is big and slow so almost anyone can hit it. 

'And then once you can pass one balloon back and forward, try to keep two balloons going at the same time. 

'Try putting one hand behind your back - so in effect you're sort of doing a backhand, or hit one with your hand and one with your foot.'

She continued: 'We also had a cereal box table tennis. [All they needed was] two biscuit tin lids and a ping pong ball. A ping pong ball was the only thing I needed to pay for, which would be 20p from the newsagent's.

'What I realised watching them was that in order to control the ball, their hands had to be out in front and that's actually what tennis is all about - hitting the ball in front of you.'

She added: 'I became very creative with my coaching because I realised that, in general, children don't want to listen to their parents and they don't want to be taught by their parents. So if you can get them to play games that will do the teaching for you.' 

The former Strictly Come Dancing star, who is working with UK Coaching to promote Coaching Week, a nationwide celebration of coaching, explained such games were accessible to anyone, no matter what their background.

They also help children to improve their skills independently, meaning any lessons or coaching sessions can be focused on fine-tuning the technique.

Andy Murray is currently recovering from an injury that has ruled him out of the start of the season. He is said to be hoping to return to the court in time for Wimbledon. 

Judy added: 'He's doing everything that he can to get ready. You can't rush anything. We still hope he'll be ready for the grass season. We just have to keep our fingers crossed.' 

Join UK Coaching in celebrating great coaching and supporting Coaching Week from 4-10 June 2018 and share your #GreatCoaching experiences on social media. For more info, visit www.ukcoaching.org/GreatCoaching
item.dc:abstract: EXCLUSIVE: Judy Murray (left), 58, told how she helped tennis ace sons Andy, 31, and Jamie, 32, learn the basics of the sport through simple indoor games that used household objects. The mother-of-two explained she invented the games as a way to keep her sons occupied at the family home in Dunblane when they were growing up. The boys had their first rally with a balloon in the living room and used to develop their skills by playing table tennis in the kitchen with biscuit lids. Pictured right, Judy with Andy in 2011.
item.dc:creator: Kerry Mcdermott
item.mi:shortTitle: Judy Murray reveals tennis games she invented for sons Jamie and Andy

item.title: How Hugh Grant was finally tamed: Tracey Cox reveals what it took to persuade an 'eternal bachelor' to finally marry at 57
item.description: Hugh Grant and Anna Eberstein married in an intimate ceremony in Chelsea just over a week ago - here Tracey Cox reveals what prompted him to finally relinquish his 'eternal bachelor' status.
item.content:encoded:
'Who knew Hugh Grant could act?' was the question on everyone's lips when the highly acclaimed BBC drama A Very English Scandal aired a few weeks ago.

Now it's 'Who knew Hugh Grant would get married after all this time (or have five children, by the way)?'

Even close friends were surprised when Grant finally tied the knot in a small ceremony in Chelsea Registry Office a bit over a week ago – this is the man who famously called marriage 'boring' and 'unromantic', after all.

So why did the 'eternal bachelor' finally settle down at the grand old age of 57 and, after dating some of the world's most beautiful women – Liz Hurley and Jemima Khan among them – what does new wife Anna Eberstein have that the others apparently don't?

What makes a confirmed bachelor suddenly (or finally) change their mind?

How do you know if someone's a confirmed bachelor?

Hugh Grant ticked every box to earn his 'eternal bachelor' status.

The chances of a man marrying for the first time after age 38 drop dramatically – and even further once he reaches 42 or 43.

Even if he's battle weary, bitter and defensive, a widowed or divorced man is still more likely to marry after the age of 35 than a man who has never attempted to commit for life.

(Ditto the man who still lives with his parents and has never left home – not that this applies to Grant, but just so you know.)

Grant is often compared to the other (former) famous bachelor, George Clooney, but George did have a brief marriage to actress Talia Balsam before he married Amal.

Grant has made no secret of the fact he's not a fan of marriage.

'Do I think humans are meant to be in a 40-year-long faithful relationship? No, no, no.'

Unlike women who will often say one thing and mean another, men who say they're anti-marriage, generally are.

Confirmed bachelors like Grant use phrases like 'I like not having to answer to anyone' and 'I like doing what I please' all the time.

They also often have routines they don't like to alter.

If you meet a guy who's never been married who won't change the slightest thing about their life to accommodate you, walk away if a ring is what you're after.

There's hard evidence Grant cheated on Liz Hurley - he was arrested on Sunset Boulevard for receiving oral sex in a public place from sex worker Divine Brown - and wanting to continue to play the field is another reason men give for not wanting to settle.

We also know two women – one his now wife Anna - were bearing his sons at the same time, proving there was at least an overlap in his relationship with her and his previous partner (and mother of the other two of his children), Tinglan Hong.

Is a bachelor a commitment-phobe?

Hugh Grant might have not have believed in the institution of marriage but he definitely doesn't tick the boxes for a commitment-phobe.

The two often get lumped in together but there is a difference.

A bachelor doesn't believe in marrying; true commitment phobia is a fear of any kind of commitment that involves other people – not just relationship commitment.

Grant was with Liz Hurley for 13 years which is – let's face it - longer than a lot of people's marriages.

He dated socialite Jemima Khan for three years and others for years at a time.

More importantly, he and Liz have remained close friends ever since the split with Grant godfather to her son Damian.

He has five children in total: two with former partner Tinglan Hong and three with his now wife.

He reputedly met Tinglan in the bar, had a 'fleeting affair' (according to a statement by his publicist) and the pregnancy was an accident.

He could easily have contested it but didn't.

Grant might conduct his relationships in a way most don't.

As I said, both Tinglan and Anna were pregnant with his sons at the same time.

His first child with Anna, John Mungo, was born in September 2012; his second child with Tinglan, Felix, was born three months later in December 2012.

This didn't come out until a year later, when Grant signed a birth certificate as John Mungo's father, and he was caught on camera seeing both women, apparently simultaneously.

But he didn't shirk his responsibility, acknowledges paternity of all his children and supports them financially.

He also has a circle of close friends he's known for years, who are all fiercely supportive of him: few, if any, commitment-phobes can say the same.

They tend to shy away from intimate involvement with anyone.

Why now?

So even if he's not a commitment phobe, Grant certainly wasn't a fan of marriage - why bother with a ceremony he doesn't really believe in, six years and three kids into a relationship, three years off hitting 60?

I think it's this simple: the timing is right for him.

Some people want what he's just signed up for at 25, others don't fancy it until 57.

I got married (albeit for the second time) when I was 55 because I didn't find the person I truly wanted to spend the rest of my life with until then.

Sometimes it takes that long – especially if you've got a lot of other stuff going on, like a career.

Post 50, there's less need to prove ourselves, our libidos calm down and we start to realise our own mortality.

In short, we want different things from life.

Things that did not appeal to me at all pre-50 – routine, familiarity, being able to second-guess how your partner will react in pretty much all situations – I now find hugely attractive.

Which is a good thing because marriage is all about routine and predictability.

It's also reassuring that Grant got married six years into his relationship with Anna.

Saying 'I do' to someone, six years and three children in, is a much stronger, more realistic commitment than one made when you're in the heavy idealization stage of a new relationship, brains flooded with love and sex hormones that remove rational judgement and thought.

Having five children also changes you.

Grant is known for being miserable and nothing like the dippy, happy characters he played in Richard Curtis movies.

'Having these kids has transformed him from a very miserable person into a fairly miserable person,' said Hurley, ironically, recently.

'It's improved him. He's gone up the scale.'

Who knows - the whole idea of marriage might well have come from one of the children he has with Anna?

Why Anna?

'They have three kids' is the obvious answer to anyone asking why Anna Eberstein was the one to finally tame Grant.

A partner who is a great mother is a compelling reason to rethink old beliefs.

Anna's also bright (she's a Swedish TV producer), comes from good stock (her parents are prominent Swedish judges) and looks good, in a non-flashy way, sporting a bod to die for (and that's after three children).

If you believe in the theory that we all fall for someone who looks like us, their face shapes and proportion are remarkably similar.

Anna might be successful but she's not a star, so if Grant is a tad narcissistic, there's no competition for the limelight.

Watching videos of them together, their body language is impressive: there don't appear to be any power plays going on and they're affectionate without suspiciously over-doing it.

Just as he's finally getting the roles he's always wanted, perhaps Hugh Grant is entering a more mature, contented stage of his life.

I met him once, years ago in a restaurant in Notting Hill.

He was sitting at the table next to me and we ended up chatting: he was charming, flirtatious without being creepy and very funny.

It was around the time the media were changing their opinion of him: undecided as to whether he was a handsome playboy or seedy womanizer.

Maybe I'm biased because of this, maybe it's because his characters (apart from Jeremy Thorpe) are always so loveable, but I've always been fond of him and thought his heart was in the right place.

We've all made mistakes and at least he admits his.

Some leopards do change their spots and I have every confidence he'll last the distance.

Find more advice on sex and love on Tracey's website and her Edge and supersex ranges on lovehoney.co.uk
item.dc:abstract: The British actor Hugh Grant and Anna Eberstein married in an intimate ceremony in Chelsea just over a week ago - here Tracey Cox reveals what prompted him to finally relinquish his 'eternal bachelor' status, and what makes a confirmed bachelor change their mind.
item.dc:creator: Martha Cliff
item.mi:shortTitle: Tracey Cox reveals what it took for Anna Eberstein to tame Hugh Grant

item.title: Time for new family photos? Kate and William send out thank you cards with an old picture of Princess Charlotte – after using the same portrait two years in a row for their own missives
item.description: The thank you card sent to those who wished Charlotte a happy third birthday features a picture taken at Kensington Palace in January as she set off for her first day at nursery.
item.content:encoded:
Royal fans who sent good wishes to Princess Charlotte on her third birthday were no doubt delighted to receive a thank you card from the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge.

But if they were hoping to see a new image of the little Princess on the front they were left disappointed as Kate and William opted for an old portrait of their daughter on her first day of nursery. 

The card, which was shared to Instagram by a royal fan, features a picture taken at Kensington Palace, released in January this year as Charlotte set off for the Willcocks Nursery School in London.

It bears the message: 'The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge thank you for so kindly writing as you did to Princess Charlotte on the occasion of her third birthday.

'This was most thoughtful of you, and greatly appreciated by Their Royal Highnesses who send you their best wishes.'

The card has emerged just a day after it was revealed that Kate and William used the same portrait two years running on a card sent to people who wished them well on their wedding anniversary.  

As is custom William and Kate sent thank you notes to everyone who had been kind enough to send their best wishes on their seventh wedding anniversary on April 29, 2018.

Fronting the card was a photo of the couple during their India and Bhutan tour in 2016 - exactly the same image the palace used last year. 

In the photo the Duke and Duchess are seen smiling before the camera during their Himalayan trek to Bhutan's Tiger Nest monastery. 

Photos of the card were shared by royal fan Jessica, 22, from Italy on her Instagram account Royal Addicted 2, which boasts over 200,000 followers. 

The note on the card, which remains the same for all recipients, reads: 'The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge thank you for the thoughtful message you so kindly sent on the occasion of their 7th wedding anniversary.

'It was really thoughtful of you. Their royal highnesses send you their warmest thanks and very best wishes.' 

Both the image and the message, aside from the year of the anniversary, are identical to last year's thank you cards. 

Last year's card was shared on a regular well-wisher's Instagram account Royal Letters with only difference being the absence of a cream border.  

The MailOnline has contacted Kensington Palace for a comment.  

The couple have previously been criticised for sending out identical messages of thanks on every occasion. 

While nobody expects a personalised response, the royal couple can't seem to come up with a different message for each new batch of cards.

Not only do they send the same 'warmest thanks and best wishes' time after time, but the message on their cards is identical to that used by Prince Charles and Camilla.

The faux pas was revealed by an Instagram account Royal Letters, which shows that Kate and William have sent out the same response on no fewer than four separate occasions. 

It seems that the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge are still yet to broaden their vernacular as they are still sending their 'warmest thanks' and 'best wishes'.
item.dc:abstract: The thank you card sent to those who wished Charlotte a happy third birthday was shared to Instagram. It features a picture of Charlotte taken at Kensington Palace in January as she set off for her first day at nursery (left). Yesterday, it emerged that Kate and William have used the same portrait for their anniversary thank you cards two years running (right).
item.dc:creator: Siofra Brennan
item.mi:shortTitle: Kate and William send thank you cards with old picture of Charlotte

item.title: 'It's like Mean Girls!' Three mothers reveal what the middle-class school run is REALLY like, with fierce cliques, body-shaming and bitchy looks rife
item.description: EXCLUSIVE: Far from being a support network, the cliques that form at the school gates can be a masterclass in bullying, say UK-based mums who've seen the catty side of the school run.
item.content:encoded:
Far from being an opportunity to chat with like-minded parents, the minutes before the bell rings at 3:30pm can actually be torturous if you don't fit in with the myriad of cliques that quickly pool at the school gates.

At least that's the experience of three middle-class mothers who, speaking exclusively to FEMAIL, say they've had to endure everything from dagger looks over outfits to assumptions that they must be the nanny, based entirely on the colour of their skin.

Far from being a supportive network of friends experiencing their children's educational journey together, life at the school gates can be treacherous if you don't fit in, they say, with conversations revolving around who has the swishest car, takes the nicest holidays and can afford the best ballet tutor.    

Here, they lift the lid on the literal front line of parenting, where death stares are served up as freely as the post drop-off coffee: 

'COMPETITION IS FIERCE, FROM HAVING TENNIS LESSONS TO THE CAR YOU DRIVE AND THE HOLIDAYS YOU TAKE...'

Ar’nie Krogh is in her early forties and has lived in the UK for more than ten years. Originally from Singapore, the mother-of-four endured a negative experience while living in Surrey, where her husband's job was based. The family have since moved their children's education to London. 

Says Ar'nie: 'I am from Singapore and it is natural in our culture to be well dressed and outgoing. I didn’t really think anything of it by turning up to the school gates with a short skirt or high heels on - to me it is normal. Unfortunately the other mums didn't approve.

'To be honest, I was blasé about it all to begin with... but I soon realised I was not going it fit in. 

'The ladies all looked the same and would huddle up into their groups and I felt excluded. I could see they would stare and then look away quickly and talk about me.

'On one occasion, one of the ladies came up to me and I thought "oh, they are going to chat to me, they must be warming up to the newbie" only to be asked politely "Do you think its appropriate to be wearing that?"

'I was a bit gobsmacked; my outfit was not inappropriate, just a bit glam - it was summertime and I was wearing a skirt. 

The lady then suggested that my boss would not be happy if he knew I was collecting the children the way I was dressed. This is when I realised she thought I was the 'help' and not the 'mum'. I sweetly responded saying: 'He doesn’t mind - I am sleeping with him!'.

I don’t think she saw my sense of humour and she thought I was actually sleeping with the boss. She soon reverted back to the group where all of the other mums turned and stared over.

 One lady suggested my boss wouldn't be happy if he knew I was collecting the children the way I was dressed. This is when I realised she thought I was the 'help' and not the 'mum'. I responded saying: 'He doesn’t mind - I am sleeping with him!'
 London school mum, Ar’nie Krogh

Luckily we were not based in Surrey for a long time; I dreaded the school run every day - I felt like I was back at school and judged by my every move. It was not a nice feeling. 

Now, living in London you still get those cliquey groups at the school gates and it is very hard to make friends.

It is all about social hierarchy and keeping up with the Joneses - the more tick boxes you tick off the social calendar, the more integrated and accepted you are into the local society.

The pressure is on to do tennis lessons, be a member of that club, holiday here, wear this, drive that car, make sure the kids have piano or tap lessons by this particular teacher. 

Even the children feel it as the adults almost burden their own children with the pressure of getting the right results, to ensure they score high enough to get accepted into a certain school. The competition is fierce.

I met a friend at the school gates and we were chatting and we have started having coffee after we drop off the kids. It is good to know I am not alone and we have set up a little social group called 'you can sit with us' - no matter what your background, social status, you can join us - it offers a message about inclusion and exclusion. 

'I CHANGE MY CLOTHES BEFORE PICK-UP TO AVOID STARES'

Zahra Andersen was born in the mountains of Afghanistan and fled to Europe when the Taliban took over. While studying in Denmark, Zahra met and married her husband John and the couple moved to the UK so he could be closer to his two children from a previous marriage. While she describes communities in Denmark as open and friendly, she says the school gates in the UK have been a different experience.

'I clearly remember the first couple of months when my children began school in England, the pick-ups were awful.

'I felt judged by the other mothers. The way they would look at me made it obvious [they didn't like me].  

Zahra says that her previous experiences in other countries were entirely different and that picking up her children at the school gates can feel like 'going back to high school' where you feel 'excluded' for no reason.'

'I work in the fashion industry and so have to dress fashionably, but as I don't automatically fit into a pack it can be difficult to make friends. 

'I now just try and keep myself to myself and even change my clothes before I pick up my children so as not to draw attention.'

She says the only reason she tones down her outfits is because she doesn't want her children to feel left out but admits she has found it tough breaking into English social circles. 

'Every mum is in their own clique - there are the 'sporty mums', the 'Range Rover' mums, the 'high-powered working' mums but no one intermingles openly and it can feel lonely at the school gates. It can be like Mean Girls.'

Zahra adds that she's keen to be accepted into social circles because she wants to be accepted for the sake of her children.  

'THERE IS A CERTAIN WAY YOU SHOULD ACT TO FIT IN' 

Dina Maktabi lives in Kensington with her two children, who attend a French school in the upmarket West London postcode. Her husband runs a bank in Beirut and she travels to Lebanon, where she was born, frequently. Dina runs a blog for parents in the borough of Kensington and Chelsea and wants to unite parents at the school gates after her own negative experiences.  

She says: 'I feel different from the other mums due to my background and heritage. 

'Even though London is a very culturally diverse city, it is noticeably apparent that there is a certain way you should act to 'fit the pack' like the other mums at the school gate.'

Dina says she tries to avoid doing anything that might make her stand out from the crowd, saying: 'You need to try and blend in without looking out of place as they will assume you are different.'

She says the lack of support she has experienced herself as a mother led her to set up her blog, Kensington Mums.  

'Being a mother is a great blessing and I am grateful for it every day. It's hard work, and there is no book in this world that will prepare you for what is yet to come.

'Since becoming a mother over ten years ago, I have gone through my share of baby blues, feeling of loneliness and isolation. 

Dina explains: 'Life is completely different to me as a mother in London - having no family around or support network, and also being the first from my group of friends to get married and have children; I want other mums to never feel alone and to keep them in the loop.

London is such a cosmopolitan city with lots of international Mums, from all walks of life. What is nice is the community connection we are trying to grow.

That's something I am proud of, as our children also get exposed to different cultures and nationalities to prepare them for the real world.'
item.dc:abstract: EXCLUSIVE: Far from being a ready-made support network, the cliques that form at the school gates can be a middle-class masterclass in bullying, say three women who've have experienced feeling targeted and isolated on the school run. London-based parents (pictured from left) Ar'nie Krogh, Zahra Andersen and Dina Maktabi have lifted the lid on the catty atmosphere that can fester at pick-up time.
item.dc:creator: Joanna Tweedy
item.mi:shortTitle: Mothers reveal the fierce cliques at the school gates

item.title: Can YOU spot the frog among the leaves? Artist behind some of the internet's favourite brainteasers reveals a baffling new puzzle - and fans say it's his hardest yet
item.description: Hungarian artist Gergely Dudas - or Dudolf - as he is known to fans, shared a new brainteaser on Facebook on Tuesday, asking players to find the frog tucked away amid the vibrant green leaves.
item.content:encoded:
Internet artist Gergely Dudás is back to infuriate his fans with more mind-boggling puzzles.

Dudolf, as he is known to his fans, shared a new brainteaser on Facebook on Tuesday, asking users to find the frog among the leaves.

The busy scene features a mass of jungle plants in various shades of green and purple, making it extremely tricky to spot the amphibian lurking in their midst. 

Over 2,000 fans have already attempted to find the frog - but can YOU spot him? 

Scroll down for solution 

Eagle-eyed players should be able to spot the creature in the lower right hand side of the drawing - but you shouldn't feel down-trodden if you can't.

Many have described the puzzle as Dudolf's 'hardest yet' in comments on Facebook, admitting it took them up to ten minutes to find the frog. 

One fan wrote: 'This was probably the hardest one for me, but I found him!'

Another agreed adding: 'This one took me like 10 times longer than the others, the frog is so small, so well hidden! Kudos!' 

The Hungarian cartoonist is behind some of the internet's best-loved visual puzzles.

In May he challenged users to spot a single lollipop among dozens of ice creams.

With a sea of the frozen treats, all in very similar shades, it is almost impossible to spot the lolly.  

Players should be able to spot the smiling lollipop towards the top right hand corner of the picture.

A number of people claimed they found the lollipop quickly but enjoyed the puzzle. 

One person said: 'Took 2 second to find the lollipop but spent 3mins laughing at the horrified 2 cones and the one licking them'

Another wrote: 'The green ice-cream near the left top corner and with a big smiley face has caught my attention...I can't take my eyes from it to spot the lollipop'  

He also released a special Easter puzzle for fans.

Somewhere in this vibrant flower patch there is a single bee buzzing around for honey - but only the most eagle-eyed players will be able to pick it out. 

Last year's Easter offering, a single egg hidden in a busy garden, was challenging, but this one is undoubtedly more difficult. 

For those looking for a clue, the yellow bee is flying between two blooms of the same colour. 

Dozens of fans commented to say how tricky they had found the puzzle after Dudolf shared it on his Facebook page.  

One posted: ' It's so hard to find it because the flowers are tiny and the bee is so small.' 

Another agreed: 'I had to put my glasses on for this one ~ but I found it!'

Dudas became an online sensation after his deceptively difficult seek-and-find puzzle featuring a panda hidden among a group of snowmen swept the internet in December 2015. 

He now produces puzzles for most major holidays - and delights followers by posting random editions throughout the year. 

At Christmas Dudas released a new book, Bear's Merry Book of Hidden Things, which uses colourful illustrations and seek-and-find puzzles to tell the story of a bear getting ready for a Christmas party.

While the title is aimed at children, the puzzles are tricky enough that they will keep parents entertained, too.
item.dc:abstract: Hungarian artist Gergely Dudas - or Dudolf - as he is known to fans, shared a new brainteaser on Facebook on Tuesday, asking players to find the frog tucked away amid the vibrant green leaves. It's been liked by thousands of his fans - many of whom branded the puzzle his toughest yet - but can you spot the hidden frog?
item.dc:creator: Martha Cliff
item.mi:shortTitle: Can YOU spot the frog among the leaves?

item.title: Step aside, Abbey! Elle Clancy admits she compared herself to her ‘taller and thinner’ sister as she stuns in a new swimwear campaign – and says she’s the ‘tomboy’ of the family
item.description: EXCLUSIVE: Elle Clancy, 20, who is based in London, said that Abbey is 'very supportive' of her modelling career'. Elle stars in new swimwear campaign for Faith at Debenhams.
item.content:encoded:
Elle Clancy has admitted that she would compare herself to her 'taller and thinner' older sister Abbey while growing up.

The model, 20, revealed that she's 'definitely more of a tomboy' compared to Abbey, 32 - describing the way they look and dress as 'very different'. 

However, she said that Abbey is 'very supportive' of her modelling career, with her top piece of advice being to 'just be yourself'.

It comes as Elle features in a stunning new swimwear campaign for Faith at Debenhams, which was shot over two days in Tenerife. 

Speaking to FEMAIL, the model said: 'I'd say [Abbey and I] are quite different. The way we look, and how we dress, is quite different. I'm more of a tomboy, definitely more of a tomboy. 

'I was always like why aren't I so tall, so thin - I was always comparing myself to her. She's gorgeous, she's beautiful' . 

Elle explained how Abbey, who began her own career has model, has given her advice as she begins her career.

'We're all very close, we're a very close family. Abbey's really supportive. She's really happy for me,' she said.

 'She tells me "Just be yourself, you're doing what you love". She's an inspiration to a lot of people, including me.' 

Elle starred in her first magazine shoot at the age of just 13, when she was shot by renowned photographer Tim Walker for Love magazine.

She also took part in Liverpool Fashion Week that year, with big sister Abbey supporting her from the front row. 

Since then, she has taken in a number of glamorous shoots, regularly sharing behind-the-scenes snaps on Instagram page. 

However, it has not been all plain sailing for Elle, who was diagnosed with polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) two years ago.

Explaining how she struggled with the condition, she said: 'I didn't know what it was for a long time, but I was struggling with my weight - it was going up and down.

'My skin all came up in lumps. I was so embarrassed, I didn't want to leave the house. 

'I was trying everything, and nothing would help. Then I went to see a specialist and she said, 'I don't think it's your skin, it's your ovaries.'  

The model, who also works as a hair stylist, explained how she has had to transform her diet and fitness regime in order to keep the condition under control. 

'It is really difficult to manage it. It's made me really into fitness, which I really love now,' she said. 'I train at least once a day.' 

'I'm very careful with what I eat. No dairy, I've cut down on sugar, I don't really drink any more.

'It's taken me two years to work out what's best for my body. Now I've got it under control I feel so much happier, healthier and fitter.' 

Elle is open about her battle with PCOS on her Instagram page, offering advice to her fans who also suffering with the condition. 

She described how modelling has helped her regain her confidence, and said she is know looking forward to working on other projects in the future.  

'It's definitely given me confidence, you feel proud of what you've achieved,' she said.

'I want to work with brands that I genuinely do like. We'll see what happens.' 

The Faith swimwear range is available at Debenhams now.
item.dc:abstract: EXCLUSIVE: Elle Clancy, 20, who is based in London, said that Abbey (inset) is 'very supportive' of her modelling career, with her top advice being to 'just be yourself'. The model explained how she had to transform her diet and exercise regime after being diagnosed with polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) two years ago. It comes as Elle features in a stunning new swimwear campaign (left and right) for Faith at Debenhams, which was shot over two days in Tenerife.

item.mi:shortTitle: Elle Clancy admits she compared herself to older sister Abbey
