item.title: Harry had 'emotional' last phone call with 'tearful' ex-girlfriend Chelsy Davy a week before his big day - and she promised not to gatecrash his reception after guest list 'snub'
item.description: A family friend said that Chelsy Davy, 32, was in 'tears' during a phone call to Prince Harry ahead of his wedding with the former couple acknowledging that he was 'moving on'.
item.content:encoded:
Most of us would avoid inviting any old lovers to our wedding but Prince Harry was brave enough to invite two to his.

However, it seems that his nuptials bought back some old feelings for ex-girlfriend Chelsy Davy who is said to have had an 'emotional' phone call with the prince just a week before the nuptials on Saturday.

According to Vanity Fair the 32-year-old got in touch with her ex last week - after discovering that she had been invited to the ceremony but not the reception at Frogmore House, and the conversation acted as closure for the former couple.

A family friend told VF: 'It was their final call, a parting call in which they both acknowledged Harry was moving on.

'Chelsy was quite emotional about it all, she was in tears and almost didn't go to the wedding. 

'In the end, she went and promised Harry she wouldn't try and gatecrash the party.' 

MailOnline has contacted Kensington Palace for a comment. 

The 32-year-old, who dated the prince from 2003 to 2010, attended the ceremony of Meghan Markle's wedding to Prince Harry on Saturday.

She is reported to have arrived with fellow ex-girlfriend Cressida Bonas, with the pair spotted chatting together ahead of the ceremony. 

Many social media users were quick to point out the jewellery designer's more somber face during the service. 

While many joked that her pensive face screamed 'it should have been me', others admitted that they could relate to her. 

Body language expert Judi James, says that Chelsy's feelings were evident during the wedding.

She told the MailOnline:  'When she arrived, everyone else was chatting and laughing, but she sat in the pews just looking to one side - gazing reflectively into space and biting her lips slightly. 

'She was doing that at the end as well. It was almost the soap opera part of the ceremony.'

Chelsy and Harry have stayed amicable since breaking up in 2010 after a seven-year romance. In 2011 they went to Prince William's wedding together.  

Harry’s invitation to his exes will be seen by many as a sign of his maturity. 

The Prince, 33, enjoyed a tumultuous seven-year romance with law graduate Chelsy, 32, while his relationship with actress Cressida, 29, who was introduced to him by Princess Eugenie, foundered after two years.
item.dc:abstract: A family friend said that Chelsy Davy, 32, was in 'tears' during a phone call to Prince Harry ahead of his wedding with the former couple acknowledging that he was 'moving on'. The 32-year-old, who dated the prince from 2003 to 2010, attended the ceremony of Meghan Markle's wedding to Prince Harry on Saturday, however she did not receive an invite to the reception at Frogmore House. Pictured: Chelsy at the ceremony (left) with Prince Harry in 2008 (inset) and Harry with bride Meghan on Saturday (right).

item.title: Move over Dr. Doolittle! Family-of-five that lives with 80 PETS, including pigs, kangaroos, alpacas, and a miniature donkey, shares glimpse into their 'wild life' in fascinating new reality series
item.description: Our Wild Life follows the lives of the Abrams family, a household of five people who run their own zoo on their 16-acre home in Pinetops, North Carolina. Pictured is mom Bobbie Jo
item.content:encoded:
A family that owns more than 80 pets in North Carolina has agreed to star in TLC's new reality show.

Our Wild Life follows the lives of the Abrams family, a household of five people who run their own zoo on their 16-acre home in Pinetops, North Carolina.

The new show premiered on Wednesday and showed how chaotic the lives of the Abrams family can be as they watch over their 80 animals including a zebra, camel, a bird named Donald Trump, and many more. 

The family zoo, called 'It's a Zoo Life', started with mom Bobbie Jo Abrams who said she has had a love for animals since a very young age.

'I would find these strays and feed them,' she said on camera. 'And my mother would say "stop feeding them or they're never gonna leave". And that was what I was hoping for.'

She described her family at the beginning of the first episode as 'multi-species' consisting of 'two beautiful girls, one little boy, and 80 fur babies.'

The home really is multi-species because the family allows for animals - such as a goat, tortoise, pig and kangaroo - roam the house throughout the day. 

Bobbie Jo's husband, Jerry, admitted on camera that he is not wild about all the animals that the family owns. But he puts up with it because of how much Bobbie Jo loves them.  

'Bobbie Jo is just a loving, caring, genuine person,' he said when asked to describe his wife.  

Most of the animals they have acquired for the zoo were rescued by the family because no one else wanted them. 

'They're each unique just like us,' Bobbie Jo said. 'It's so nice because the people that come out can see that we all need love.' 

Bobbie Jo has a special relationship with most of the animals because she is hands on with raising them. One kangaroo, named Skipper, travels with the mother-of-three wherever she goes - even to the supermarket.  

The first animal Bobbie Jo got was a rescue donkey who she named Rachel Ray. Seven years later, the zoo has grown to hold more than 80 animals and become a USDA licensed facility.  

During the first episode, viewers got to see the chaos that is the Abrams family as they attempt to manage all their animals while running the zoo.

One energetic lemur is seen leaping around the household while the family gets read and even hung out on Jerry's shoulder while they ate breakfast.  

Other members of the family include daughter Hali, 21; daughter Kasi, 18; son Jaxon, 7; and the longtime nanny Naa Naa.  

New episodes of Our Wild Life air every Wednesday on TLC.
item.dc:abstract: Our Wild Life follows the lives of the Abrams family, a household of five people who run their own zoo on their 16-acre home in Pinetops, North Carolina. The new show premiered on Wednesday and showed how chaotic the lives of the Abrams family can be as they watch over their 80 animals including a zebra, camel, a bird named Donald Trump, and many more. The family zoo, called 'It's a Zoo Life', started with mom Bobbie Jo Abrams (right) who said she has had a love for animals at a very young age. The family loves the animals so much that they even let them roam throughout the home.

item.title: 13 Reasons Why creator is slammed for graphic male-on-male anal rape scene - but he insists the moment 'doesn't come close to the pain experienced by people who go through these things'
item.description: SPOILER ALERT: The second season of the controversial Netflix series premiered on May 18, and the show is already facing backlash over an excruciating rape scene.
item.content:encoded:
The second season of the Netflix series 13 Reasons Why is already marred by controversy over a disturbing rape scene, but the show's creator is standing by his decision to feature graphic footage of a male character being sodomized with a broken mop. 

After receiving backlash for the graphic depiction of Hannah Baker's suicide in the first season of the series, the new season begins with a PSA of the show's leading cast members warning that the series 'tackles tough, real world issues' — including sexual assault and school shooting storylines. 

Despite the disclaimer, 13 Reasons Why is once again courting controversy over a scene that depicts school photographer Tyler Down (Devin Druid) being brutally beaten and raped by three student-athletes in the season finale. 

After being ostracized by his peers in the first season of the show, Tyler pulls off a series of blackmail and vandalism stunts while seeking approval from a group of punk kids.

The loner is shunned by his so-called friends and sent to a behavioral rehab program after he gets caught vandalizing the school baseball field, resulting in a canceled season.

When he returns to school, school-athlete Monty (Timony Granaderos) and two other jocks follow him into the bathroom to sexually assault him as revenge. 

The disturbing scene begins with Monty bashing Tyler's head against the sink before calling him a 'f****t' and dragging him to a stall to dunk his head in the toilet. 

As Tyler pleads for mercy, the two other athletes hold him down while Monty takes a mop handle and forces it up his rectum. The excruciating pain is visible on Tyler's face, and when Monty finally removes the mop handle, it is covered with blood.

Monty tosses the mop on the ground before they leave, and Tyler is left crying on the ground, his head resting on the wall of the bathroom stall.

The two minute scene was directed by Kyle Patrick Alvarez, the same director who filmed the controversial depiction of Hannah (Katherine Langford) slitting her wrists in the bathtub in season one.

Critics have called this season's rape scene 'disgusting' and 'unnecessary,' while the Parents Television Council has issued an 'urgent warning' about the show. Referring to the new season as a 'ticking time bomb to teens and children,' the council has called for the cancellation of the series. 

For all the criticisms, there are also those who have supported the show's exploration and graphic depiction of real issues plaguing teens across the country.

13 Reasons Why creator Brian Yorkey has defended the inclusion of the scene, telling New York magazine's Vulture: 'We are committed on this show to telling truthful stories about things that young people go through in as unflinching a way as we can.' 

Last year, amid criticisms of the first season of the teen drama based on Jay Asher's best-selling book of the same name, Netflix added an additional warning card at the start of the series.  

Changes that were implemented for the new season include the custom introduction with the cast, an after show, and additional resources listed at 13ReasonsWhy.Info, including a viewing guide.

In his shared statement, Yorkey noted that Netflix has provided resources 'for understanding that this may not be the show for everybody,' as well as resources for those who are troubled by why they saw while watching it. 

'But the fact is that, as intense as that scene is, and as strong as are or reactions to it may be, it doesn’t even come close to the pain experienced by the people who actually go through these things,' he said. 

'When we talk about something being "disgusting" or hard to watch, often that means we are attaching shame to the experience. We would rather not be confronted with it. We would rather it stay out of our consciousness,' he added. 'This is why these kinds of assaults are underreported. This is why victims have a hard time seeking help. We believe that talking about it is so much better than silence.'

Yorkey claimed the storyline came from research on real-life cases of male-on-male sexual violence in high school, and he said the decision to include the scene was supported by both Netflix and Paramount, which produces the show, following 'extensive discussions.'

In the first season of the show, Hannah and Jessica Davis (Alisha Boe) are both raped by Bryce (Justin Prentice), and Yorkey pointed out that those scenes didn't receive the same amount of backlash because the victims were women. 

'The very, very intense scene of Hannah’s suicide seemed to overshadow the fact that Hannah and one other girl were violently raped in season one,' he said. 

'If there’s a greater sense of backlash about this scene, especially it being hard to watch, "disgusting," or inappropriate, that goes to the point that we need to be talking about the fact that things like this happen. 

'The fact that this would be somehow more disgusting than what happened to Hannah and Jessica, I’m shocked but not surprised.'  

The episode has also come under fire over a subsequent scene in which a traumatized Tyler takes an automatic rifle to the school dance with the intention of shooting his fellow students.

It is a continuation of the school shooting storyline that was introduced in the first season finale, and while he doesn't end up going through with the massacre, critics have found the scene to be troubling considering the unyielding plague of gun violence going on in the country. 

TWITTER REACTS TO GRAPHIC 13 REASONS WHY RAPE SCENE 

The second season of 13 Reasons Why premiered on Friday, May 18, at midnight Pacific time, and less than six hours later, Dimitrios Pagourtzis, 17, opened fire at Santa Fe High School near Houston, Texas, killing 10 people. 

Netflix canceled the Los Angeles premiere party scheduled on Friday evening for its second season because of the school shooting.

The controversial release also follows the February shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Florida, in which 17 people were killed.   

Two weeks before the show's season two premiere, Yorkey opened up about Tyler's storyline, telling The Hollywood Reporter: 'We had a character who was obviously severely bullied, suffering from social isolation and was thinking of making a very tragic choice in addressing those feelings for himself.

'With season two ... we're very interested in continuing to follow his journey and to try to understand his state of mind and the state of his soul,' he continued. 'I think you'll see in the balance of the episodes that it's very much about trying to understand Tyler's character and how a troubled young man might be driven to consider this very difficult choice.'

The showrunner said it is up to the audience to decide of the show has successfully addressed the issue in a way that sparks conversation about gun violence without glorifying it.

'Unfortunately, there's a great deal of literature about a great number of troubled young men who resorted to or almost resorted to violence to act through their feelings,' he said. 'So we were able to study a great deal of the history there, and we tried to be authentic and honest and also accurate in our portrayal of the character. 

'As with all things with the show, our hope was that we could honestly represent the experience; that our viewers might, through the experience, learn more and start more conversations about those issues in their own world.'  

Season one of the series faced similar criticisms over Hannah's graphic suicide scene, as well as the depiction of two female characters being raped.

People accused the show of glorifying suicide, and many mental health professionals agreed that such a realistic portrayal could lead to copycat suicides among teens.
item.dc:abstract: GRAPHIC CONTENT AND SPOILER ALERT The second season of the controversial Netflix series premiered on May 18, and it is already facing backlash over an excruciating scene showing Tyler Down (Devin Druid) being being brutally beaten and raped by three student-athletes. During the assault, Tyler is sodomized with a broken mop and left weeping. Critics of the rape scene have called it 'disgusting' and 'unnecessary,' while the Parents Television Council has issued an 'urgent warning' about the show. Creator Brian Yorkey has defended the scene, explaining 'it doesn’t even come close to the pain experienced by the people who actually go through these things.' Season one of the series faced similar criticisms over a graphic suicide scene, as well as the depiction of two female characters being raped.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Lankston
item.mi:shortTitle: 13 Reasons Why creator is slammed over anal rape scene

item.title: Have YOU got a 'Toblerone tunnel'? Stars show off the latest bizarre Instagram craze that's been dubbed 'the new thigh gap'
item.description: The 'Toblerone tunnel' - a triangular-shaped gap formed by the bottom and the tops of the upper thighs named after the popular chocolate bar - is currently sweeping celebrity bikini pictures.
item.content:encoded:
From the 'thigh brow' to 'hip cleavage', there's no shortage of bizarre body crazes to follow - but the latest celebrity trend sweeping Instagram might just be the most extreme yet.

The 'Toblerone tunnel' - a triangular-shaped gap between the upper thighs named after the popular chocolate bar - is currently sweeping celebrity bikini pictures.

Stars including Kendall Jenner and Emily Ratajkowski have been taking to social media to show off their own in rather racy selfies. 

British reality stars have been getting in on the action too, with Made In Chelsea's Louise Thompson and TOWIE's Katie Wright sharing their own sizzling rears. 

Here, we reveal the celebrities who have been proudly showing off their very own Toblerone tunnels...

item.title: How to turn $500 into more than $100,000: Financial expert who saved $36,000 in 13 months shares her four simple strategies for building wealth
item.description: Financial expert Canna Campbell - who saved $36,000 in 13 months on top of her regular salary - revealed that if you put aside your rebate of $500 each year, you can save up to six figures.
item.content:encoded:
When given a sum of money like $500, it can be easy to think it's too small a figure to be worth investing.

But one financial expert is here to tell you that you can turn a repeated investment of $500 a year from a government rebate into as much as $129,000.

Canna Campbell - who famously saved $36,000 in 13 months on top of her regular salary - revealed that if you simply put aside your rebate of $500 each year rather than just assimilating it into your lifestyle, you can save up to six figures.

Recently, she shared her four simple strategies for building wealth - and explained that wealth creation isn't so much about how much you earn, but what you do with what you earn.

Scroll down for video

1. Put your money into a diversified balance managed fund or ETF

Canna's first example is that you could take your $500 government rebate year after year and put that money into a diversified balance managed fund or ETF.

'People earning between $48,000 and $90,000 can receive up to $530 a year in a government rebate,' she explained in a video on the subject. People earning less than this will receive slightly less. 

'Set it aside out of temptation into a diversified balance managed fund or ETF. All you need to do is invest the $500 initially, and then year after year just continuously add that government rebate into that investment portfolio.'

If you never take any out, but rather let the money re-invest over time, Canna said after ten years, with an average interest rate of five per cent, you would have $6,211 invested.

'Using this $500 for your immediate financial benefit and long-term financial benefit is a good idea,' Canna added.

Total after ten years; $6,211. 

2. Use your $500 to help pay down non-deductible toxic debt

Canna uses the example of someone with a $400,000 mortgage, who has an average interest rate of 6.5 per cent on a 25 year term.

'If they were to take that $500 rebate and put it on their home loan, and continuously put that $500 rebate on their home loan year after year after year, that person would save over $12,331 and pay off their mortgage eight months earlier,' Canna said. 

'Paying down non-deductible debt, using $500, is a fantastic strategy.'

Total after 25 years: $12,331 - mortgage paid off eight months earlier

3. Use your $500 for your superannuation

Lots of us drift through life without thinking too much about our superannuation - that is until it hits us that we need to start thinking about it.

But according to Canna, if you invest that $500 rebate each year into your superannuation, you could end up $39,000 better off.

'Put it in as an after tax contribution,' she explained. 'Yes, once you have it in, you can't get it out. But it means you're removing temptation because that money is then invested for your long-term benefit.'

Canna used the example of someone aged 28 with $22,000 already in their super, earning around $35,000 a year with employer contributions going into her account.

'If they actually put their $500 in there year after year, then by the time they reached age 65, then they would have over $306,000 in their superannuation account.' 

She added that this means they would be $39,000 better off than if they just went away and spent that cash each year.

Total at age 65 years: $39,000

4. Buildup a diversified investment portfolio

Last but not least, Canna highlighted this strategy as the single best at making you extra wealth.

'You can do this through a managed fund, you can do this by investing in the ETF, or you can do this by investing in investment companes,' she said.

And whether you hand it over to an expert or do it by yourself, the principle is the same - to set up an investment portfolio.

'If you were to take your rebate and continuously invest it year after year after year, putting $500 religiously into that portfolio, with all of the dividends being re-invested, if you did did this for 40 years, with an average interest rate of eight per cent, then you would have over $129,528 in that investment portfolio over 40 years,' she said.

And the best thing of all is that you would have only invested $20,000 of your own money over that time - meaning you'd made a profit of over $109,000.

'This is the magic of compound interest working as magic for you over a long period of time. It's a simple way to build wealth.'

Total after 40 years: $129,528

To find out more from Canna Campbell, visit her website here.
item.dc:abstract: Financial expert Canna Campbell (left and bottom right) - who famously saved $36,000 in 13 months on top of her regular salary - revealed that if you simply put aside your rebate of $500 each year rather than just assimilating it into your lifestyle, you can save up to six figures. She shared her four simple strategies for building wealth - and explained that wealth creation isn't so much about how much you earn, but what you do with what you earn.
item.dc:creator: Sophie Haslett
item.mi:shortTitle: Financial expet's four simple strategies for turning $500 into $100K

item.title: Thrifty Kate strikes again! Duchess of Cambridge stuns in an Alexander McQueen coat that she has worn THREE times before
item.description: Kate, 36, wore a primrose yellow silk tailored coat as she entered the Chapel by Alexander McQueen, the label which designed her wedding dress.She made a statement in an oversize hat is by Philip Treacy and shoes by Jimmy Choo.
item.content:encoded:
The Duchess of Cambridge reached for a familiar favourite when getting dressed for Prince Harry and Meghan Markle's wedding today. 

Mother of three Kate, 36, wore a primrose yellow silk tailored coat by Alexander McQueen - the label behind her own wedding gown - that she's previously worn on no less than three high profile occasions.  

She was first seen in the designer piece for the christening of Princess Charlotte back in July 2015, and then wore it again a year later for the Trooping of the Colour in June 2016.

She was seen most recently wearing it at the Passchendaele commemoration service during a visit to Belgium back in July last year. 

And Kate, who gave birth to her third child, Prince Louis, less than a month ago, wore her investment piece once again today at the wedding of the year, teaming it with an oversized Philip Treacy hat and Jimmy Choo heels. 

While Kate was not an official bridesmaid, the mother-of-three could be seen guiding her children Charlotte, three, and George, four, who were flower girl and pageboy, down the aisle. 

The Duchess was accompanied by fellow mum Jessica Mulroney, who was also helping to assemble her children who are also part of the bridal party.

The Cambridge's nanny Maria Borrallo was also on hand to support the royal children in their wedding duties. 

Ahead of bride Meghan's arrival, the bridesmaids and pageboys were ushered in by Kate, who helped coax them into their positions with an encouraging hand on their shoulder.  

The 36-year-old royal took her seat alongside Prince Charles and Camilla for the ceremony as her husband Prince William took his place as best man next to the groom.

The trio could be seen singing in hymns as part of the ceremony ahead of the Meghan and Harry's reception at Frogmore house later this afternoon.

Kate's youngest, Prince Louis, appears to have remained at home as at just three weeks old was deemed to young for the ceremony. 

The Duchess of Cambridge is still on her official maternity leave which began at the end of March.

Aside from Thursday's wedding rehearsal and today she may appear at some family occasions during the summer but is not expected to return to official duties until the autumn, according to aides, and even then her 'primary focus' will be her children.

Other members of the Middleton family were also in attendance today including Kate's parents Carole and Michael Middleton and her two siblings James and Pippa.

The sister of the Duchess of Cambridge, who is thought to be around four months pregnant, showed just a hint of her baby bump this morning as she set off from London with her husband James for Harry and Meghan's big day.

Pippa, 34, wore a pretty £495 Hepburn silk floral dress from brand of the moment, The Fold which features a close-fitting bodice and pleated skirt.

The expectant mother teamed her ensemble with nude suede shoes and a bespoke Jess Collett Milliner hat in blush with hand dyed flowers, straw honeycomb shards and a sinamay bow.

The ceremony itself was an emotional one with both Harry and Meghan fighting back the tears. 

As she arrived at the altar Harry grabbed his bride's hand and told her: 'You look amazing' and said 'thank you, pa' after his father Prince Charles walked her down the aisle of St George's Chapel, Windsor.

But the tears turned to laughter when the star made him giggle as they exchanged vows in the extraordinarily moving ceremony watched by millions around the world.

Ms Markle’s wedding dress has been designed by the acclaimed British designer, Clare Keller, the first female Artistic Director at the historic French fashion house Givenchy.

The veil was held in place by Queen Mary’s diamond bandeau tiara, lent to her by The Queen, made in 1932 - an outfit that left her mother Doria Ragland, 62, in tears.

Meghan arrived accompanied by two page boys who held up her train as she made her way up the chapel’s steps alone and entered the chapel by herself, to begin the walk down the alter, before being met by the Prince of Wales.
item.dc:abstract: Kate, 36, wore a primrose yellow silk tailored coat as she entered the Chapel by Alexander McQueen, the label which designed her wedding dress. The coat may seem familiar to royal watchers as the thrifty duchess has worn it no less than three times before. She was first seen in the designer piece for the christening of Princess Charlotte back in July 2015 (far right) and then wore it again a year later for the Trooping of the Colour in June 2016 (second from right). She was seen most recently wearing it at the Passchendaele commemoration service during a visit to Belgium back in July last year (second from left).
item.dc:creator: Martha Cliff
item.mi:shortTitle: Duchess of Cambridge stuns in an Alexander McQueen coat at wedding

item.title: Fergie's big moment: Beaming Duchess of York is back in the fold as she joins illustrious guests at Windsor Castle – after 2011 royal wedding snub
item.description: The Duchess of York, 58, beamed with delight as she joined the stream of well-heeled guests pouring into St. George's Chapel this morning - a far cry from her tears over the 2011 royal wedding snub.
item.content:encoded:
She admitted to feeling 'totally worthless' after being left off the 2011 Royal wedding guest list.

So it's little wonder Fergie was in such high spirits today as she joined a host of hand-picked VIPs at the nuptials of her nephew Prince Harry at Windsor Castle.

The Duchess of York, 58, beamed with delight as she joined the stream of well-heeled guests pouring into St. George's Chapel this morning.

Dressed in a navy skirt suit, Jess Collet hat and towering heels, Sarah arrived separately from her daughters and ex-husband, who followed with the rest of the royal family at 11:20am, via the Galilee Porch.

Beaming widely and waving to crowds, Sarah was seen giving her future son-in-law, Jack Brooksbank, a hug before heading inside.

She told reporters: 'I have had a lovely day and it is wonderful to see so many people out for this lovely occasion.' 

While she is reportedly not invited to this evening's knees-up at Frogmore House, her presence at the ceremony represents an important milestone for the Duchess, who has excluded from countless royal engagements since her acrimonious split from Prince Andrew in 1992.

Despite being one of the 600 guests invited to this morning's ceremony, Sarah was said to be ‘deeply unhappy’ about being excluded from tonight's private evening do.

Fergie has remained close to her nephew despite difficult family politics; she went skiing with Harry and his then-girlfriend Cressida Bonas in 2013, and the groom is particularly close to her youngest daughter Eugenie.

According to insiders, Fergie has been complaining about the ‘snub’ to anyone who will listen – although some couriers think she should count herself lucky to be going at all.

Prince Harry personally intervened to make sure she had an invitation to his wedding to Meghan Markle and the first reception after years in the royal wilderness.

It is understood that Sarah had already been introduced to Meghan ahead of the big day, but it is thought that Charles, who is paying for the evening reception at Frogmore House, doesn’t approve.

An insider told the Mail: ‘Numbers are limited to the evening party, she is not a member of the Royal Family any more and Prince Charles simply doesn’t have time for her.

'He just can’t see why she is still such a big part of his brother’s life.’ 

The Duchess wasn’t invited to the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge’s 2011 wedding at Westminster Abbey, and took herself off to a spa in Thailand instead - later admitting to feeling 'ostracised'. 

While Sarah is invited to a small number of occasions, such as Royal Ascot and the family’s summer break at Balmoral, the Queen reportedly has to take care that she doesn’t appear when Prince Philip is around.

The 96-year-old is said to hold a deep-seated grudge against the duchess for the embarrassment he feels she has heaped upon his family over the years - once reportedly describing her as ‘having no point’.

There were the infamous images of her having her 'toes sucked' by financial adviser John Bryan in 1992, and then the 2010 cash-for-access scandal. 

Speaking about a potential clash between Fergie and Philip a few weeks ago, a source told the Mail: ‘It will be fascinating to see if the Duke of Edinburgh acknowledges her.  

'He has held a grudge against her for a long, long time and normally refuses to even be in the same room as her.’

Earlier this year the Daily Mail told how Sarah's wedding invite had caused a ‘massive headache’ behind the scenes.

Senior royals, led by Charles and Philip, had reportedly made it clear that they didn’t want the duchess there, but Harry, who is fond of her, held his ground. 

‘He absolutely, 100 per cent wants her there and has told palace officials that in no uncertain terms,’ a source said at the time.

But source close to the duchess said: ‘The duchess was delighted to be asked to the wedding and to be there for Prince Harry. 

'She did not expect in any way to be asked to the smaller evening reception. She is divorced from Prince Andrew although close to him and as with most families it is not usual to invite ex aunts and uncles. 

‘She was touched to have been included in the wedding service and reception.’ 

Despite their 1996 divorce, Sarah and Andrew remain extremely close and live at Royal Lodge, his Windsor home, together. 

In an interview with an Australian radio show in 2016, Sarah said: 'I always think, "have we really?". We're divorced to each other right now. We've never really left each other.'
item.dc:abstract: The Duchess of York, 58, beamed with delight as she joined the stream of well-heeled guests pouring into St. George's Chapel this morning - a far cry from her tears over the 2011 royal wedding snub. Dressed in a navy skirt suit, Jess Collet hat and towering heels, Sarah arrived separately from her daughters and ex-husband, who will follow with the rest of the royal family at 11:20am, via the Galilee Porch.
item.dc:creator: Unity Blott
item.mi:shortTitle: Proof Fergie is back in with the royal family?
